study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of a physiotherapist-delivered combined physical and psychological intervention (BOOST programme) compared to best practice advice for improving walking and disability in older adults with neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The study assessed outcomes using the Oswestry Disability Index, 6-Minute Walk Test, and other measures at 6 and 12 months, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract. The primary analysis was intention-to-treat, with parallel health economic and qualitative evaluations.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65+ with neurogenic claudication due to spinal stenosis.
effective_dosage: Twelve 90-minute classes (including education, exercises, and walking circuits), plus home exercises and two support calls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and safety of Guanxinjing capsule (GXJ) compared with placebo in alleviating symptoms and improving quality of life in patients with chronic stable angina.
results_summary: The study abstract does not provide results, as it describes a planned trial rather than reporting outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with chronic stable angina (Qi deficiency and blood stasis syndrome).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal exercise, including brisk walking, reduces the odds of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), gestational hypertension (GH), and pre-eclampsia (PE).
results_summary: The study found that exercise-only interventions, including brisk walking, significantly reduced the odds of GDM, GH, and PE by at least 25% when pregnant women accumulated at least 600 MET-min/week of moderate-intensity exercise.
population_specificity: Pregnant women without contraindication to exercise.
effective_dosage: At least 140 minutes of brisk walking per week (equivalent to 600 MET-min/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the psychometric properties of beam walking distance as a measure of dynamic balance, its relationship with other balance tests, and its accuracy in predicting falls.
results_summary: The study expects beam walking performance to more accurately predict fall risks and falls compared to traditional balance outcomes, though final results are pending.
population_specificity: Healthy adults across 7 decades (n=432) and patients with Parkinson's disease, multiple sclerosis, stroke, and balance disorders (n=100).
study_duration: Cross-sectional with follow-ups at 6 and 12 months for participants aged 50+.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of CRT-d patients with diabetes treated with GLP-1 RA plus conventional hypoglycemic therapy versus those treated with conventional hypoglycemic therapy alone.
results_summary: CRT-d patients treated with GLP-1 RA showed significant improvements in NYHA class, 6-minute walking test performance, and CRT-d responder rates, along with reduced AF and VT events and fewer hospitalizations for heart failure worsening.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes treated by cardiac resynchronization therapy with a defibrillator (CRT-d).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review interventions targeting free-living physical activity (including walking) and/or sedentary behavior in adult stroke survivors to assess their promise and identify effective behavior change techniques.
results_summary: Six out of nine studies were rated as very/quite promising, reporting increases in physical activity post-intervention. Face-to-face and telephone-based self-management programs showed promise in engaging stroke survivors in physical activity behavior change, with nine specific behavior change techniques identified as effective.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors (first or recurrent stroke or transient ischemic attack).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify preoperative predictors of performance-based measures (PBMs) like stair climbing, walking speed, and gait speed at least 6 months after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) for osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Low-quality evidence suggests preoperative functional ability and quadriceps muscle strength are associated with functionality 6 months post-TKA. The study highlights a need for improved reporting of predictor analyses to guide clinical management.
population_specificity: Individuals who underwent primary TKA for osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term and long-term cost-effectiveness of two pedometer-based walking interventions compared with usual care in primary care settings.
results_summary: The postal delivery of a pedometer intervention was found to be cost-effective long-term, with a 50% chance of being cost-effective within 1 year, resulting in more QALYs and lower costs compared to control and nurse support groups. The nurse support group showed incremental cost-effectiveness for increasing MVPA bouts.
population_specificity: Adults aged 45-75 years without physical activity contraindications (short-term) and a simulated cohort aged 59-88 years (long-term).
effective_dosage: 12-week walking programs with pedometers and PA diaries, delivered either by post or through three PA consultations with practice nurses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether treadmill workstations in offices could increase daily walking time among sedentary office workers.
results_summary: The study found that treadmill workstations led to a statistically significant increase in daily walking time (18 minutes more in the intervention group compared to 1 minute in the control group), though the effect was smaller than expected.
population_specificity: Healthy office workers aged 40-67 years who were overweight or obese, with sedentary work tasks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Morning Walk training improves walking ability, lower limb function, and balance in stroke patients with hemiparesis compared to conventional physiotherapy.
results_summary: Morning Walk training significantly improved walking ability, lower limb function (measured by Motricity Index-Lower), and balance in stroke patients, with greater improvements in voluntary strength and balance compared to conventional physiotherapy alone.
population_specificity: 58 patients with hemiparesis following a first-time stroke within the preceding year and with Functional Ambulation Category scores ⩾2.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of training with Morning Walk (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze changes in clinical characteristics of COPD patients under the 2017 GOLD classification system and explore its role in comprehensive assessment.
results_summary: The 2017 GOLD reclassified more patients into Groups A and B, who had worse lung function and higher BODE index. Groups B and D may have greater disease severity, but the new system's prognostic and drug guidance effectiveness requires further study.
population_specificity: 631 stable COPD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of intra-articular implantation of autologous bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) for treating knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Patients receiving MSCs showed significant improvements in WOMAC scores, pain, physical function, and painless walking distance compared to placebo, with no major adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grades 2, 3, and 4).
study_duration: Single administration (follow-up duration not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs) on left ventricular diastolic function, exercise capacity, and quality of life in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that MRAs improved early diastolic mitral annular velocity in HFpEF patients, but the abstract does not mention any results related to walking.
population_specificity: HFpEF patients (755 participants across 6 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether very early mobilisation (within 48 hours of stroke onset) improves recovery outcomes, such as independence, compared to usual care in acute stroke patients.
results_summary: Very early mobilisation did not significantly increase survival or good recovery rates but may have reduced hospital stay by about one day. There was a slight, non-significant increase in deaths with VEM, raising concerns about potential risks when mobilisation starts within 24 hours.
population_specificity: People with acute stroke.
effective_dosage: Mobilisation started as early as 13.1 hours (median 18.5 hours) after stroke onset, with a median difference of 12.7 hours earlier than usual care.
study_duration: Follow-up was a median of three months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity home-based respiratory muscle training could improve respiratory muscle strength, endurance, dyspnea, and walking capacity in post-stroke patients with respiratory muscle weakness.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant improvements in inspiratory and expiratory muscle strength, endurance, reduced dyspnea, and enhanced walking capacity compared to the control group. The effects were greater than those reported in studies using standard protocols.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling post-stroke patients with respiratory muscle weakness (N=38).
effective_dosage: 40-minute high-intensity home-based respiratory muscle training, 7 days per week, progressed weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) could improve knee pain and physical function, specifically walking distance, in individuals with preradiographic knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that TENS significantly improved both pain scores (VAS) and walking distance in the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) for participants with early-stage knee osteoarthritis. No significant improvements were noted in other functional tests like the stair climb or TUG test.
population_specificity: Patients aged 50-69 with knee pain (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 0 or 1).
effective_dosage: Not specified (TENS device worn under the patella, activation details not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (pre-post design, exact duration unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of participant-selected strategies in reducing workplace sitting time and increasing purposeful walking among desk-based workers.
results_summary: The study found that each additional strategy for standing up was associated with a significant reduction in prolonged sitting (27.6 min/8-h workday). Task-based and phone-based strategies were common, and specific strategy categories were linked to reductions in total sitting and increases in purposeful walking.
population_specificity: Desk-based workers (n=134 in the intervention group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants were guided to choose their own strategies, including standing time with sit-stand workstations).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of VR therapy, including virtual walking, on neuropathic pain in spinal cord injury (SCI) patients.
results_summary: Virtual walking and other VR methods reduced neuropathic pain in SCI patients, with combined virtual walking and transcranial direct current stimulation being the most effective. The clinical significance of the analgesic effect remains unclear.
population_specificity: Adult spinal cord injury (SCI) patients with neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a 12-week online walking intervention for cancer survivors and explore psychological predictors of behavior change, particularly comparing rural and metropolitan participants.
results_summary: The intervention increased physical activity post-intervention, with a larger increase in the intervention group compared to the control group, but these changes were not sustained at the 3-month follow-up. Psychological predictors (motivation, barrier self-efficacy, relapse self-efficacy) did not differ by region but predicted changes in steps per day among intervention participants.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors, with a focus on rural and metropolitan Australians.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved individualized goal setting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability and responsiveness of the Timed Up-and-Go Test (TUG) and 2-Minute Walk Test (2MWT) in assessing mobility and their link with perceived fatigue in patients with mild multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that both TUG and 2MWT were highly reliable and responsive for assessing mobility in mild MS patients, with excellent immediate and 2-week reliability. Mobility impairments were weakly but significantly correlated with perceived fatigue.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and mild disability (Expanded Disability Status Scale ≤4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of prolonged-release fampridine on cognitive function, quality of life, mood, and fatigue in MS patients over 6 and 12 months of treatment.
results_summary: Responders to fampridine showed statistically significant improvements in walking speed (T25FW), information processing speed (SDMT), and quality of life (MSIS29, MUSIQOL) after 6 and 12 months, but no improvements in memory, subjective fatigue, or mood. Non-responders showed no significant improvements.
population_specificity: MS patients (responders n=40, non-responders n=20).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tolerability, adherence, and efficacy of a community walking training program with simultaneous cognitive demand (dual-task) versus a control walking program without cognitive distraction in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The dual-task group showed greater improvement in the Physical Activity Scale for the Elderly (PASE) score compared to the control group, but no significant differences were found in other measures. The study suggests dual-task training might increase activity over 12 weeks, but the results are not conclusive.
population_specificity: Adult stroke survivors at least 6 months post-stroke with visibly obvious gait abnormalities or reduced 2-min walk distance.
effective_dosage: 10-week, bi-weekly, 30-minute treadmill program at an aerobic training intensity (55%-85% heart rate maximum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the functional and clinical outcomes, as well as adverse effects, of osseointegration for patients with limb amputations compared to conventional socket prostheses.
results_summary: Osseointegration improved functional outcomes (walking ability, prosthetic use, mobility), satisfaction, and quality of life, but was associated with an increased risk of soft tissue infection, mostly treatable with antibiotics. No severe adverse events like additional amputation or death were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with limb amputations managed with osseointegrated prostheses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively describe functional alterations in the midfoot joints of adolescents with plano-valgus feet compared to normally-developed feet during walking.
results_summary: The study found that plano-valgus midtarsal joints were more dorsiflexed, everted, and abducted with reduced sagittal-plane range of motion compared to controls, indicating significant postural and kinematic alterations during walking.
population_specificity: Twenty adolescents (13.3 ± 0.8 years) with bilateral plano-valgus feet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate functioning and health-related quality of life determinants in patients with anti-MAG neuropathy, focusing on walking performance (6MWD) and its predictors.
results_summary: The study found that 6-minute walk distance (6MWD) was a reliable predictor of physical health-related quality of life (PCS), with Berg balance scale (BBS) and Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS) being strong determinants of 6MWD. Fatigue (FSS) also significantly impacted mental health-related quality of life (MCS).
population_specificity: 67 patients with anti-MAG neuropathy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of active mind-body movement therapies (AMBMTs) like tai chi, qigong, and yoga versus pulmonary rehabilitation (PR, often involving walking) in managing COPD.
results_summary: AMBMT showed statistically significant improvements in disease-specific quality of life compared to PR (mainly unstructured walking), but no differences in dyspnoea. Adding AMBMT to PR improved generic quality of life but not disease-specific QoL.
population_specificity: Adults aged 55-88 with COPD, predominantly male (78%), mostly from China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions lasted at least four weeks with no minimum frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of arch support foot orthoses versus a sham condition on lower limb kinematics and kinetics during walking in children with flexible flat feet.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in lower limb alignment and ground reaction forces during walking in the foot orthoses group compared to the sham group, including changes in ankle, knee, and hip angles.
population_specificity: 30 boys aged 8-12 years with flexible flat feet.
effective_dosage: Not specified (foot orthoses used during everyday activities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Thai traditional dance improves balance performance in older women compared to normal daily activities.
results_summary: The study found that Thai traditional dance significantly improved balance and mobility, including reduced sway velocity, faster weight transfer, quicker turn time, and better walking speed compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Older women aged 60-80 years with moderate balance scores on the Berg Balance Scale.
effective_dosage: Three dance sessions of 30-60 minutes per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in patient willingness for surgery and factors influencing this shift after participation in a digital nonsurgical osteoarthritis treatment program involving education, exercise, and physical therapist interaction.
results_summary: The study found that 31% of participants initially willing to consider surgery no longer did so after 6 weeks, while 6% of those unwilling at baseline reconsidered in favor of surgery. Reduced pain and improved quality of life were linked to decreased willingness for surgery, while worse pain, lower quality of life, and walking difficulties were associated with increased willingness.
population_specificity: 458 individuals (mean age 62 ± 5.6 years, 67% women) with diagnosed hip or knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits of walking for middle-aged and older patients with diabetes and metabolic syndrome, while also assessing the associated risk of injurious falls due to neuromuscular decline.
results_summary: Walking provides significant health benefits for middle-aged and older patients with diabetes and metabolic syndrome but carries a risk of falls, particularly for those with neuromuscular decline. The study suggests that clinical tools, including electrodiagnosis, could help identify at-risk individuals and improve targeted interventions.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older patients with diabetes and metabolic syndrome, particularly those with distal neuromuscular decline or neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide evidence-based recommendations on prenatal physical activity, including walking, to improve maternal, fetal, and neonatal health outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that prenatal physical activity, including walking, is associated with significant maternal health benefits (e.g., reduced risk of preeclampsia, gestational diabetes, and depression) and fewer newborn complications (e.g., large for gestational age), with no identified harms. Physical activity was not linked to adverse outcomes like miscarriage or preterm birth.
population_specificity: Pregnant women without contraindications.
effective_dosage: Not specified (general recommendations for physical activity frequency, duration, and volume).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a 12-week mixed power training program on physical function in obese older men with varying severities of dynapenia.
results_summary: The study found that obese older men with severe dynapenia had poorer baseline physical function but showed significant improvements in fat and lean mass, functional performance, handgrip strength, and lower limb muscle strength and power after the intervention. The training effects varied slightly between the two dynapenia severity groups.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling obese older men (69 ± 6 years) with dynapenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of dyskinesia on activities of daily living (ADLs), including walking, and the effects of ADS-5102 (amantadine) extended-release capsules versus placebo in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that dyskinesia significantly impacted walking and balance in 63%-73% of patients at baseline. ADS-5102 treatment significantly reduced the patient-rated impact of dyskinesia on walking and other ADLs, as well as clinician-rated dyskinesia intensity and disability.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients with troublesome dyskinesia (≥1 h/day) and at least mild functional impact of dyskinesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a perioperative anesthetic and pain treatment protocol in managing postoperative pain and functional recovery (including walking ability) for patients undergoing total hip or knee replacement.
results_summary: The study found that the pain treatment protocol provided very good pain control (mean NRS scores of 1.3 for both THR and TKR) and enabled patients to achieve standard functional abilities (walking 50 meters and climbing stairs) within a mean of 8 days without medication-related complications. Rescue therapy use correlated with pain scores.
population_specificity: 100 patients (50 total hip replacement and 50 total knee replacement) in a hospital setting.
study_duration: Mean length of stay until functional recovery was 8 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of home-based moderate-intensity walking on functional capacity, activities of daily living, and body composition in patients with advanced gastrointestinal cancer during chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that walking improved postural sway and lean body mass compared to the control group, and may stabilize functional capacity. However, gait speed, peripheral neuropathy, and strength did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced gastrointestinal cancer (UICC III-IV) undergoing first-line chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes of moderate walking per week.

study_goal: The study does not address Walking; it evaluates the safety and efficacy of a Chinese herb formula (YFN) combined with standard Western treatments for stable COPD.
results_summary: The study does not provide results related to Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a structured education program with text-message support could effectively and cost-effectively increase walking activity in individuals with a history of coronary heart disease (CHD).
results_summary: The study assessed the impact of a group-based education program on walking activity, measured via step count, but the abstract does not provide specific results on efficacy. Secondary outcomes included cardiovascular risk factors, self-efficacy, and quality of life, though detailed findings are not reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥18 years, 12 to 48 months post-diagnosis of a CHD-related cardiac event (myocardial infarction, angina, or acute coronary syndrome).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included two group-based education sessions and text-message support).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how much body weight support people with knee osteoarthritis place through a walking cane and whether a brief training session could increase this support.
results_summary: Before training, participants placed an average of 7.2% of their body weight through the cane. After a 10-minute training session, there were significant increases in peak body weight support (28%), average support (25%), and impulse (54%), though individual responses varied.
population_specificity: Seventeen individuals with knee pain who had not used a walking cane before.
effective_dosage: Not specified (training aimed for at least 10% body weight support).
study_duration: 1 week of cane use followed by a 10-minute training session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association of different exercise interventions, including walking, with venous leg ulcer (VLU) healing when used alongside compression therapy.
results_summary: Walking was studied in one RCT (35 participants) and showed an association with increased VLU healing at 12 weeks, though the effect was imprecise. The most effective intervention was progressive resistance exercise combined with prescribed physical activity.
population_specificity: Participants with venous leg ulceration (VLU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) compared to structured exercise (SE) or their combination in improving walking distance and blood flow in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: RIC alone, SE alone, and RIC plus SE all significantly improved pain-free walking distance and ankle-brachial pressure indices, with no significant differences in improvement magnitude between the groups. The study suggests RIC is as effective as SE for intermittent claudication, with no added benefit from combining the two interventions.
population_specificity: Stable intermittent claudication patients (n=40 completed the trial).
effective_dosage: RIC involved 4 cycles of 5-min upper limb ischemia followed by 5-min reperfusion, administered every 3-4 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of motor-assisted elliptical training (ICARE) on walking and fitness in a child with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that the child improved fitness, walking speed, stability, endurance, and performance on the modified Time Up and Go test after 24 sessions of ICARE training. The intervention demonstrated clinically meaningful gains in both fitness and function.
population_specificity: A 12-year-old boy with spastic diplegic cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System II).
effective_dosage: Primarily moderate- to vigorous-intensity ICARE exercise (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: To examine the long-term effects of a 12-week LBPP-supported low-load treadmill walking regimen on knee pain, function, and thigh muscle strength in overweight patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Patients maintained improvements in knee pain, joint function, and thigh muscle strength for at least 6 months post-intervention, with significant reductions in acute knee pain during full weight-bearing walking.
population_specificity: Overweight patients with knee osteoarthritis (n=19).
effective_dosage: 2 sessions per week, 30 minutes per session at 3.1 mph and 0-degree incline with LBPP support.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the characteristics of prosthetic gait and balance among children and adolescents with lower-limb amputation or limb loss.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in gait and balance parameters between children with lower-limb amputations and typically developing children, including increased load on the intact leg during balance tasks and lower performance in dynamic balance tests.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with lower-limb amputation or limb loss.

study_goal: To assess the effect of quadriceps strengthening on quadriceps muscle force, power, and work and tibio-femoral compressive loads during walking in adults with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Quadriceps strength training improved muscle strength, pain, and function but did not alter quadriceps or knee joint biomechanics during walking. Maximum negative quadriceps power increased in the training group, likely due to faster walking velocity.
population_specificity: Adults with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether three-curve rocker-soled shoes could increase walking distance and alter biomechanics during pain-free and IC pain-induced walking compared to control shoes in individuals with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: Rocker-soled shoes reduced ankle power generation and altered hip, knee, and ankle kinematics but did not significantly increase initial or absolute claudication distances compared to control shoes. Both shoe types showed similar gait adaptations in response to IC pain.
population_specificity: 31 individuals with intermittent claudication (mean age 69 ± 10 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of exercise interventions, particularly gait-specific training, in improving walking function for adults with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that exercise significantly improved timed up-and-go performance, walking speed, stride length, and cadence compared to non-exercise controls, though no significant differences were observed for double-leg support time, dynamic gait index, 6-minute walk test, or freezing of gait. Cuing positively influenced stride length, while exercise duration negatively affected comfortable walking speed.
population_specificity: Adults with Parkinson's disease (1,656 patients across 40 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: To explore the dose-response relationship between frequency of interrupting sedentary time with light-intensity walking breaks and basal glucose control in Type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Frequent interruptions of prolonged sitting with 3-minute light-intensity walking breaks every 15 minutes improved fasting glucose, reduced the dawn phenomenon, and decreased night-time glycaemic variability, but did not affect night-time mean glucose.
population_specificity: 12 people with Type 2 diabetes (age 60.0 ± 3.2 years; BMI 30.2 ± 1.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 3 minutes of light-intensity walking every 15 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a 12-week multimodal intervention, including home-based walking, on physical function and other outcomes in older patients with advanced cancer.
results_summary: The study design includes supervised exercise, home-based walking with step counts and goal-setting, and supportive counseling, but specific results regarding walking's effects are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older patients (≥65 years) with advanced pancreatic, biliary tract, or lung cancer receiving palliative chemotherapy, immunotherapy, or targeted therapy.
effective_dosage: Home-based walking with step counts and goal-setting (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of Ponseti treatment versus comprehensive surgical releases (CSR) on foot length, width, and contact area in individuals with unilateral idiopathic clubfoot.
results_summary: Ponseti treatment resulted in more symmetrical foot lengths, widths, and total contact areas compared to CSR, with an improvement of 1.3 shoe sizes difference, suggesting improved growth in clubfoot cases treated with Ponseti.
population_specificity: Age and height-matched cohorts with unilateral idiopathic clubfoot (n=40 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a foot ankle brace (Agilium FreeStep) versus a conventional knee unloader brace (Unloader One) in treating medial knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both braces significantly improved walking pain, pain during sports, and KOOS subscales (symptoms, pain, activity, sport, and quality of life) without significant differences between groups. The foot ankle brace had fewer side effects like bruises compared to the conventional knee brace.
population_specificity: Patients over 35 years with medial knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of intermittent vacuum treatment (IVT) combined with lifestyle changes on distal blood pressures, walking capacity, and other health outcomes in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study compared lifestyle changes alone versus lifestyle changes combined with IVT in PAD patients, focusing on distal blood pressures, walking capacity, and self-rated health. Results suggested potential benefits of IVT, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 48 patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a 12-week online walking intervention for cancer survivors and explore its impact on physical health indicators and quality of life.
results_summary: The study evaluated an online walking intervention (STRIDE) based on individualized step goals, measuring physiology, physical fitness, and quality of life at baseline, post-intervention, and three-month follow-up. Results indicated potential benefits, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Rural and urban cancer survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the strength, quality, and conclusiveness of evidence supporting the use of whole body vibration in children and adolescents with disabilities.
results_summary: The study found that whole body vibration was no better than minimal intervention, with effect sizes ranging from low to high but supported by very-low to low-quality evidence. Sensitivity analysis showed some impact on trunk bone mineral density at medium-term follow-up compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with disabilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and efficacy of functional electrical stimulation (FES) cycling exercise for improving mobility and physiological fitness in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) and severe mobility impairment.
results_summary: The study found that FES cycling was feasible and showed small-to-moderate improvements in walking speed (22.9%) and peak oxygen consumption, though adherence was high and mild adverse events occurred in the FES group.
population_specificity: Individuals with MS and severe mobility impairment (EDSS scores 5.5-6.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the latest developments in treating sporadic inclusion body myositis, focusing on the efficacy and safety of Bimagrumab and Alemtuzumab, particularly regarding improvements in walking distance and muscle strength.
results_summary: Bimagrumab showed promising initial results but failed to meet the primary endpoint of improving 6-minute walking distance or muscle strength. Alemtuzumab also showed promise but had a high risk of bias due to its open-label design and small sample size.
population_specificity: Adults over 50 with sporadic inclusion body myositis.

study_goal: To determine whether low-frequency deep brain stimulation of the substantia nigra pars reticulata combined with standard high-frequency stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus improves gait disorders in Parkinson's disease patients unresponsive to levodopa.
results_summary: Combined stimulation (COMB) and high-frequency subthalamic nucleus (HF-STN) stimulation improved gait disorders in Parkinson's disease patients, with COMB preferred by most patients. Low-frequency substantia nigra pars reticulata (LF-SNr) stimulation alone did not outperform COMB or HF-STN.
population_specificity: Six Parkinson's disease patients (mean age 59.1 years, disease duration 16.1 years) with motor fluctuations and dyskinesias.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a walking event intervention could improve life-space mobility and self-efficacy for walking tasks in patients following total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly better life-space mobility (LSA score) compared to the control group, with an adjusted mean difference of 13.9 (95% CI: 12.4-15.5). The walking event, which included various walking tasks, appeared to enhance self-efficacy for walking tasks in post-TKA patients.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent primary total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: 3.5 km walking course with specific tasks (crossing crosswalks, walking up/down stairs without railings, dirt roads, slopes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the five-repetition sit-to-stand test (5STS) and the 30-second sit-to-stand test (30STS) for predicting poor performance in the six-minute walking test (6MWT) and to evaluate patients' subjective perceptions of these tests.
results_summary: The study found that the 5STS and 30STS had similar moderate correlations with the 6MWT for predicting poor performance, but the 5STS was associated with a better patient experience. Both tests showed comparable sensitivity and specificity for predicting a 6-minute walk distance (6MWD) below 350 meters.
population_specificity: Patients with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involved physical tests, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether additional supervised physical activity during inpatient rehabilitation improved gait speed, mobility, function, and quality of life in older adults at discharge and 6 months post-discharge.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gait speed or other secondary measures between the experimental group (additional physical activity) and the control group (social activities) at discharge or 6-month follow-up. Both groups showed substantial mobility gains, but the extra physical activity did not enhance walking outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults (age >60 years) undergoing inpatient rehabilitation in two Australian hospitals.
effective_dosage: Median of 20 additional minutes per day (IQR 15.0 to 22.5) of upright activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a targeted gluteal rehabilitation program (including gait retraining, motor control, and high-intensity resistance training) improves physical activity levels and self-reported physical function in people with mild to moderate hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study compares a targeted gluteal rehabilitation program (GHOst) to a sham exercise program, with outcomes measured at multiple time points. Primary and secondary outcomes include physical function, activity levels, muscle strength, and quality of life, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: People diagnosed with mild to moderately disabling hip osteoarthritis (n=90).
effective_dosage: Weekly supervised physiotherapy sessions and daily home exercises for 12 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks (with follow-up assessments up to 25 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term effects of a 6-month pulmonary rehabilitation program on exercise capacity, quality of life, and muscle force in patients with interstitial lung diseases (ILD).
results_summary: The study found that pulmonary rehabilitation significantly improved exercise capacity (6MWD and peak work rate), quality of life, and muscle force in ILD patients, with benefits maintained at 1-year follow-up, though physical activity levels did not change.
population_specificity: 60 patients (64 ± 11 years; 62% males; 23% with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis [IPF]) with interstitial lung diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence, assessment, and pharmacological management of gait impairment and spasticity in MS patients, focusing on the effects of oral/intrathecal baclofen and THC:CBD spray.
results_summary: The study found that THC:CBD spray improved gait parameters in resistant MS spasticity, while baclofen showed equivocal results. Mobility impairment and spasticity negatively impacted HRQoL, with THC:CBD spray demonstrating consistent benefits in walking tests.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) experiencing gait impairment and spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between protein intake and physical function, including walking speed, in older adults.
results_summary: Higher protein intake (≥1.0 g/kg/day) was associated with better walking speed and lower-limb physical performance compared to low protein intake (<0.80 g/kg/day), but no significant differences were found for handgrip strength or chair rise performance.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults
effective_dosage: Very high protein (≥1.2 g/kg/day), high protein (≥1.0 g/kg/day), and low protein (<0.80 g/kg/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of exercise, including walking, on gastrointestinal symptoms, quality of life, depression, and anxiety in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The review found that exercise, including walking, had significant benefits for IBS patients, improving symptoms and quality of life, though the studies were limited by a strong risk of bias.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) (683 participants from 14 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of a future RCT using a virtual reality exercise intervention during dialysis and explore its impact on physical function compared to conventional exercise.
results_summary: Both conventional and virtual reality exercise interventions improved physical function, with significant improvements observed in sit-to-stand tests, gait speed, one-leg heel-rise, and the 6-minute walk test after 20 weeks. Adherence was similar between groups, and virtual reality was deemed feasible.
population_specificity: Eighteen subjects undergoing intradialysis combined exercise programs.
study_duration: 20 weeks (16 weeks of combined exercise + 4 weeks of either combined or VR exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare stair ascent kinematics and kinetics between single-radius (SR) and multiradius (MR) total knee arthroplasty (TKA) patients to determine which design more closely replicates healthy knee movement.
results_summary: SR TKA patients exhibited kinematics more aligned with healthy controls during stair ascent than MR TKA patients, though both groups showed significant postoperative improvements. SR TKA patients also demonstrated higher power production and sagittal moment than MR TKA patients, though still below healthy controls.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty (TKA), specifically comparing single-radius (SR) and multiradius (MR) designs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the functional and cognitive prerequisites for children with neurological gait disorders to walk physiologically during robot-assisted gait therapy (RAGT) with a dual-task (DT) exergame and analyze the influence of DT on leg muscle activity.
results_summary: The study found that most activity measures could distinguish between children who walked physiologically during DT exergaming or not, with moderate to good sensitivity and specificity. While DT exergaming reduced EMG-amplitudes of key stance muscles, muscle activation patterns remained highly correlated between DT and no-DT conditions.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (6-18 years) with neurological gait disorders (GMFCS levels I-IV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of treadmill training (TM) and high-velocity circuit resistance training (HVCRT) on cognition in older adults and examine relationships to aerobic fitness and neuromuscular power.
results_summary: HVCRT showed significant improvements in accuracy (ACC), global score (GS), and aerobic power (AP), with a trend toward improved reaction time (RT), while TM showed no significant within-group differences. No significant correlations were found between change scores in cognitive measures and fitness variables.
population_specificity: Older adults (30 participants, aged not specified)
effective_dosage: Exercise groups trained 3 days/week for 12 weeks, following a 2-week adaptation period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of a single 6-mL injection of hylan G-F 20 versus saline for pain relief in patients with mild-to-moderate hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both hylan G-F 20 and saline injections resulted in significant pain and function improvements over 26 weeks, with no statistically significant differences between the two treatments. Adverse event rates were similar, though posthoc analysis revealed many patients had underlying psychological or neuropathic pain conditions.
population_specificity: Patients ≥35 years with mild-to-moderate hip osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade II/III) and minimal contralateral hip pain.
effective_dosage: Single 6-mL injection of hylan G-F 20 or saline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes and gait analysis during walking between two alignment methods (mechanical vs. kinematic) in robotic-assisted total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in clinical outcomes (HSS, WOMAC, ROM, KSS) or most gait parameters between the two alignment methods, except for minor differences in varus angle and mediolateral ground reaction force. Both methods provided comparable long-term outcomes after robotic TKA.
population_specificity: 60 patients undergoing robotic-assisted TKA (30 mechanical alignment, 30 kinematic alignment), with gait analysis performed on 10 matched patients per group.
study_duration: Median follow-up of 8.7 years (mechanical) and 8.4 years (kinematic).

study_goal: The researchers were reviewing recent literature on PTSD treatments for military personnel, not specifically studying Walking.
results_summary: The abstract discusses PTSD treatments, including psychotherapy and emerging drug therapies, but does not mention Walking.
population_specificity: Military men and women with PTSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how symmetrical lower limb joint involvement in juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) patients affects gait dynamics and plantar pressure distribution.
results_summary: JIA patients exhibited slower walking speeds, reduced joint extension, and altered plantar loading patterns, including increased peak pressure at lateral midfoot and metatarsal regions, correlating with limited ankle motion during push-off.
population_specificity: Fifty JIA patients with symmetrical hip, knee, and ankle joint arthritis and 27 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inter- and intra-rater reliability of the modified Wisconsin Gait Scale (WGS) for observational gait assessment in children with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The modified WGS demonstrated very high inter- and intra-observer reliability, with strong statistical correlations (Spearman's rank correlation coefficient ≥ 0.9, ICC > 0.9, and CV < 2.5%). The tool was found to be useful for qualitative gait assessment in this population.
population_specificity: 34 children with spastic hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
study_duration: Not specified (assessment performed twice by three independent examiners).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of walking and other environmental factors in reducing obesity prevalence, particularly in children.
results_summary: The study suggests that greater access to parks, playgrounds, and active commuting (including walking) is associated with lower body mass index, highlighting the importance of built environment policies in promoting physical activity.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents, with a focus on Australian populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining physical and cognitive training (PTCT) improves walking speed, reduces dual-task cost in walking speed, lowers fall incidence, and enhances executive functions more effectively than physical training (PT) alone in older adults.
results_summary: The study design suggests potential benefits of PTCT on walking speed, fall prevention, and executive functions, but specific results are not yet provided as the study is ongoing. The abstract highlights the expected value of the findings for promoting safe walking in older adults.
population_specificity: 70-85-year-old community-dwelling sedentary or at most moderately physically active men and women in Jyväskylä, Finland.
effective_dosage: Not specified (follows current physical activity guidelines for PT; PTCT includes additional web-based cognitive training).
study_duration: 12 months (with outcomes assessed at 6 and 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a physical activity intervention program (primarily walking) on cardiovascular disease risk, health-related quality of life, and blood pressure control in hypertensive subjects.
results_summary: The walking intervention reduced cardiovascular disease risk and systolic blood pressure while improving several areas of health-related quality of life. The program also increased the percentage of subjects with controlled blood pressure, independent of baseline control.
population_specificity: 207 hypertensive subjects (average age 68.2 years, 76.8% women).
effective_dosage: 120 minutes per week of supervised walking, plus socio-cultural activities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the prevalence, risk factors, and clinical characteristics of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD).
results_summary: The study found that 6.8% of AECOPD patients had VTE, with risk factors including history of VTE, prolonged immobility, lower limb pain, and higher d-dimer levels. Walking difficulties were noted as a symptom more common in VTE patients, but the study did not evaluate walking as an intervention.
population_specificity: Hospitalized AECOPD patients (average age 72.0 ± 9.1 years, 761 males) from 16 hospitals in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate a modified treatment protocol for severe tetanus in resource-constrained settings, not specifically related to walking.
results_summary: The study found that 57.1% of patients recovered completely, 14.3% recovered with sequelae (including walking impairments), and 28.6% died. No significant adverse events were recorded.
population_specificity: 42 patients with severe tetanus treated at Surya Kanta Hospital, Bangladesh, in a non-ICU setting.

study_goal: To investigate the efficacy of two unloader knee braces on reducing medial meniscus strain during dynamic activities, including walking, in knees with intact and deficient anterior cruciate ligaments.
results_summary: Both braces significantly reduced posteromedial meniscal strain in knees with intact anterior cruciate ligaments during dynamic activities, but neither had a significant effect on anteromedial strain or in anterior cruciate ligament-deficient knees.
population_specificity: Cadaveric specimens and simulated kinematics from a healthy individual.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between mental health and intermittent claudication perception, reporting, and treatment in patients with peripheral artery disease.
results_summary: The study found that individuals with higher levels of depression had lower pain acceptance, poorer quality of life, and greater dissatisfaction with function. Mental disorders like depression and type D personality influenced symptom reporting and treatment adherence, though results were inconsistent regarding IC severity and treatment effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with peripheral artery disease who reported symptoms of intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether omega-3 fish oil and losartan, alone or in combination, could reduce inflammation and improve walking speed in older adults with mobility impairment.
results_summary: Recruitment goals for omega-3 were exceeded, but losartan and combination strata fell short due to high use of angiotensin receptor blockers or ACE inhibitors. The study successfully randomized 289 participants, with a 19:1 telephone screen to randomization ratio and a 4.5:1 first screening visit to randomization ratio.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 70+ with elevated interleukin-6 levels and mobility impairment.
interactions: High proportion of participants taking angiotensin receptor blockers or ACE inhibitors affected recruitment for losartan and combination strata.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate and describe the methods used to assess toe walking in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The systematic review found heterogeneity in qualitative methods and a lack of structured quantitative tests to assess toe walking in ASD subjects, with most studies focusing only on walking behavior.
population_specificity: Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) exhibiting toe walking behavior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of repetitive botulinum toxin A therapy (BoNT-A) combined with intensive rehabilitation on lower limb spasticity, motor function, and brace use in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in spasticity (measured by MAS), range of motion, walking speed, and balancing ability after the first treatment cycle, with persistent benefits through subsequent cycles. One-third of brace users discontinued brace use, particularly those with a forward gait pattern prior to therapy.
population_specificity: Thirty-five post-stroke patients with lower limb spasticity receiving BoNT-A for the first time.

study_goal: To compare the effects of self-ankle mobilization with movement training versus the same training with a 10° inclined board on motor function in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: Both training methods improved motor function, but the inclined board method showed significantly greater improvements in ankle dorsiflexion, balance, and gait parameters. The results suggest that the inclined board enhances the benefits of standard rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 28 chronic stroke patients with hemiplegia
effective_dosage: 3 times per week for 30 minutes per session

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of brisk walking versus Tai Chi in reducing cardiovascular disease risk factors and improving psychosocial well-being in adults with hypertension and additional risk factors.
results_summary: Brisk walking showed no significant changes in cardiovascular disease risk indicators compared to the control group, but it was less effective than Tai Chi in reducing blood pressure, fasting blood sugar, glycated hemoglobin, perceived stress, and improving mental health and exercise self-efficacy.
population_specificity: Adults aged 30-91 years (mean 64.4) with hypertension and at least two but not more than three modifiable cardiovascular disease risk factors (e.g., diabetes, dyslipidemia, overweight, physical inactivity, smoking).
study_duration: 3 months of supervised intervention, with 6 additional months of encouraged home-based practice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of contextually tailored walking suggestions delivered via the HeartSteps mHealth intervention in increasing short-term step counts.
results_summary: Delivering walking suggestions increased the 30-minute step count by 24% (59 steps) on average, with a stronger initial effect (107% or 271 steps) that diminished over time. Antisedentary suggestions had no detectable effect on step counts.
population_specificity: 44 adults
effective_dosage: Up to five contextually tailored suggestions per day at user-selected times

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pooled effect of strength training on muscle strength and functional capacity, including walking performance, in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: The study found that strength training significantly improved walking speed by 16.3% and distance covered in the 2-minute walking test by 6.7%, with moderate effect sizes (0.54 and 0.50, respectively). Walking performance appeared significantly improved, though methodological inconsistencies limited broader conclusions.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of physical exhaustion on local dynamic stability (LDS) and automaticity of gait in young adults.
results_summary: The study found no effect of fatigue on LDS during single-task walking but observed an interaction effect for LDS in the dual-task condition and motor dual-task costs, suggesting increased gait automaticity after total exhaustion.
population_specificity: 30 young and healthy adults
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was a shuttle-run test to maximal exhaustion)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a home-based cardiac telerehabilitation (HBCTR) program involving outdoor walking/jogging for low-risk post-PCI patients in China.
results_summary: The HBCTR group showed significant improvements in walking distance (6MWT), quality of life (SF36), nicotine dependence (FTND), and depression (CDS) compared to the usual care group. The intervention was more effective than standard care in enhancing recovery outcomes.
population_specificity: Low-risk Chinese patients after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
effective_dosage: Outdoor walking/jogging with real-time physiological monitoring (specific frequency/duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and describe variables under which cognitive-motor interference (CMI) is particularly useful to assess patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: MS patients showed significant CMI, with velocity, cadence, and double support being sensitive motor variables, and Alternate Alphabet, Serial Subtracting 7s, and Verbal Fluency being sensitive cognitive tasks. The study concluded that CMI should be assessed with standardized dual tasks like Verbal Fluency while walking, measuring double support time and cognitive task effects.
population_specificity: Patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the psychometric properties of performance-based outcome measures for assessing ambulation in individuals with lower limb amputations.
results_summary: The study identified valid and reliable clinical measures for ambulation in this population but noted gaps in reporting guidelines and the need for further research on minimally clinical important differences.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower limb amputations (LLA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between recreational physical activity, particularly walking, and the incidence of heart failure (HF) in older women, specifically examining HF with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) and HF with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: Higher levels of physical activity, including walking, were inversely associated with reduced risks of overall HF, HFpEF, and HFrEF, with statistically significant trends observed across incremental activity levels. Walking, the most common form of activity, showed consistent inverse associations with HF risks.
population_specificity: 137,303 women aged 50 to 79 years, free of HF and able to walk at least 1 block without assistance at baseline.
effective_dosage: Not specified (activity levels were self-reported and categorized into tertiles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of kinesiotape (KT) and athletic tape (AT) on foot and tibial motion during walking in individuals with chronic ankle instability (CAI).
results_summary: KT increased foot eversion during early stance but had no effect during late stance, while AT increased tibial internal rotation during late stance but had no effect during early stance. KT provided a flexible pulling force that facilitated foot eversion without restricting natural movement in late stance.
population_specificity: Twenty subjects with chronic ankle instability (CAI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure associations between activity patterns (avoidance, pacing, persistence) and outcomes including walking, pain-interference, and functional ability in chronic pain patients.
results_summary: The study found small to moderate improvements in observational outcomes like walking (Cohen's d: 0.37 to 0.64), with persistence ("overdoing") associated with beneficial outcomes and avoidance linked to negative psychosocial effects.
population_specificity: 891 chronic pain patients undergoing functional rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to create a framework for task complexity of concurrent motor and cognitive tasks with gait in people with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Gait velocity was significantly slower in the MCI group under all tasks, with complex cognitive tasks like serial seven subtractions causing a greater reduction in gait velocity (31.8%) in the MCI group compared to controls. The study established a framework for task difficulty in dual-task assessments.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling people with MCI (n=41, mean age=76.20±7.65 years) and cognitively normal controls (n=41, mean age=72.10±3.80 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of interval walking exercise combined with acute green tea extract supplementation on postprandial blood glucose response in physically inactive individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of interval walking and green tea extract (EX-GTE) resulted in a likely beneficial 9% reduction in blood glucose area under the curve during an oral glucose tolerance test.
population_specificity: Twelve physically inactive participants (nine male, three female; age 22 ± 1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of initial and long-term responsiveness to PR-fampridine in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) and assess its effects on walking performance.
results_summary: The study found that severity of walking disability, particularly poor baseline 6MWT performance, strongly predicted enhanced responsiveness to PR-fampridine. A multivariable model accurately predicted responder status, and long-term responsiveness correlated with declining walking endurance.
population_specificity: 55 people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) in the initial trial, with a subset of 32 followed longitudinally for 3 years.
study_duration: 6 weeks for each treatment phase (PR-fampridine and placebo) in the initial trial, with a 3-year follow-up for the longitudinal analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of hybrid assistive limb (HAL) treatment for improving ataxic gait and balance in patients with cerebellar hemorrhage and other etiologies.
results_summary: The study found that HAL treatment potentially improves ataxic gait and balance problems, suggesting it as an effective and promising treatment modality for selected cases. Future studies should assess gait appearance and balance alongside walking speed for comprehensive evaluation.
population_specificity: Patients with ataxic gait due to cerebellar hemorrhage and other etiologies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the inverted pendulum model accurately represents level gait in individuals with unilateral transfemoral amputation compared to able-bodied individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the inverted pendulum model described able-bodied gait well, but individuals with unilateral transfemoral amputation showed significant deviation during prosthetic-limb stance, which may explain their increased metabolic cost of gait. The temporal divergence could serve as a tool to assess prosthetic device efficacy.
population_specificity: 10 individuals with unilateral transfemoral amputation and 15 able-bodied participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of core strength training (CST) and Tai Chi Chuan (TCC) on musculoskeletal and cardiopulmonary function in older adults, and to test the effectiveness of combined CST and TCC training.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Walking, as the study focuses on CST and TCC. The outcomes will be evaluated at baseline, 13 weeks, and 25 weeks, but no findings are reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged participants meeting eligibility criteria).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focuses on CST and TCC, not Walking).
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 25 weeks.

study_goal: The study aimed to analyze lesion patterns causing forearm instability in acute Essex-Lopresti injury, including one case caused by a fall while walking, and propose new terminology for identification.
results_summary: The study reported improved clinical outcomes in patients treated surgically for acute Essex-Lopresti injury, with one case involving a fall while walking requiring additional surgery for persistent wrist pain.
population_specificity: Five patients with acute Essex-Lopresti injury, including one case caused by a fall while walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate effect of hip extensor and abductor taping on balance and walking ability in cane-dependent ambulators with chronic stroke.
results_summary: Non-elastic taping significantly improved balance (Berg Balance Scale), gait speed, and endurance (6-minute walk test) in the experimental group compared to the sham taping control group.
population_specificity: Cane-dependent ambulators with chronic stroke (N=28).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 12-month efficacy and effectiveness of the Urban Training intervention, which encouraged walking on urban trails, in increasing and maintaining physical activity among COPD patients.
results_summary: The study compared Urban Training (including motivational interviews, walking advice, and optional support components) to usual care in COPD patients, measuring changes in daily step count over 12 months. The abstract does not specify the magnitude of change but implies the intervention was designed to improve physical activity.
population_specificity: 407 COPD patients from primary and hospital settings.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included advice to walk on urban trails and optional components like pedometers, calendars, and walking groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of physical activity, including walking, in blood pressure management among individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that maintaining or increasing physical activity (including walking) helped stabilize or reduce blood pressure, improved endurance performance, and reduced BMI in individuals with knee osteoarthritis, while sedentary behavior led to increased blood pressure.
population_specificity: 136 participants under treatment for primary knee osteoarthritis (average age 67.6±9.6 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily physical activity levels assessed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of electrical calf muscle stimulation (EMS) combined with walking on clinical and ultrasound outcomes in patients with post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) and residual venous obstruction (RVO).
results_summary: The study found that EMS combined with walking significantly reduced recurrent DVT rates (0% in the experimental group vs. 23.3% in controls) and improved deep vein recanalization and clinical PTS outcomes (VCSS, Villalta, and CIVIQ-20 scores). Changes were more intensive in the EMS group.
population_specificity: Patients aged 40-86 with PTS and RVO after a first episode of unprovoked femoro-popliteal DVT (60 participants: 38 men, 22 women).
effective_dosage: Active walking (unspecified duration/frequency), below-knee graduated compression stockings, and micronized purified flavonoid fraction (unspecified dosage). EMS was applied 3x daily for 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if different exoskeleton software controls (ReWalk) could influence the walking ability of motor-complete spinal cord injury (SCI) patients.
results_summary: Group 2 (using the upgraded software) showed significantly better performance, covering more distance in the 6-minute walk test (+124.52%), requiring less time for the 10-meter walk test (-70.34%), and faster sit-to-stand transitions (-38.25%) compared to Group 1. The study concluded that smoother kinematic control improves functional outcomes and eliminates the influence of anthropometric factors on gait performance.
population_specificity: Fifteen chronic SCI patients (4 females, 11 males) with thoracic or lower-level motor-complete injuries.

study_goal: To determine the long-term safety and efficacy of functional surgery followed by early rehabilitation (FSER) for correcting equinovarus foot deformity (EVFD) in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found no clinical complications during the 12-month follow-up, with significant improvements in ankle kinematics, walking speed, and gait parameters maintained at 3 and 12 months post-surgery.
population_specificity: 24 adult chronic stroke survivors with EVFD (age 55±13 years, 12 left/12 right affected sides, time from lesion 5±4 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if machine learning analysis of wearable sensor data could identify subject-specific gait changes related to clinical improvements in knee osteoarthritis patients after exercise therapy.
results_summary: The study found a strong correlation (ρ = 0.78) between post-intervention gait outliers and improvements in self-reported clinical outcomes, demonstrating the potential of wearable sensors and machine learning to objectively assess movement pattern changes.
population_specificity: Eight patients with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic risk factors for the recovery of stair climbing and walking abilities in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that Barthel Index, Motricity Index, and unilateral spatial neglect at admission significantly predicted stair climbing recovery, with higher scores increasing the likelihood of recovery. Motricity Index and Trunk Control Test scores also predicted walking recovery.
population_specificity: Subjects within the first month after stroke admitted to an inpatient rehabilitation unit.
effective_dosage: Two daily 40-minute sessions of motor rehabilitation, six days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of self-report, web-based questionnaires to assess disease natural history and symptomology in genetically-defined Parkinson's disease (PD) populations, including differences in walking-related symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that LRRK2 G2019S carriers reported increased changes in walking as an initial symptom of disease compared to idiopathic PD, suggesting differences in underlying pathophysiology or disease progression. No significant differences in symptoms were observed between GBA mutation carriers and idiopathic PD.
population_specificity: Over 10,000 subjects with physician-verified PD diagnosis, including genetically-defined subgroups (GBA mutation carriers, LRRK2 G2019S carriers, and idiopathic PD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Baduanjin exercise (a form of walking-based Qigong) is beneficial for managing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that Baduanjin exercise improved exercise capability (measured by the 6-Minute Walking Test), lung function parameters (FEV₁, FVC, FEV₁/FVC ratio), and quality of life in COPD patients. The pooled effect sizes were statistically significant based on a random-effects model.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: To investigate whether cerebellar and spinal tDCS could reduce symptoms in patients with neurodegenerative ataxia and modulate cerebello-motor connectivity.
results_summary: Cerebello-spinal tDCS significantly improved performance scores, motor cortex excitability, and cerebellar brain inhibition compared to sham stimulation, suggesting symptom reduction and restored motor cortex inhibition.
population_specificity: 20 patients with neurodegenerative ataxia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of femoral nerve block (FNB) versus liposomal bupivacaine periarticular injection (LB PAI) in managing postoperative pain and functional recovery after total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found that while FNB provided slightly better pain relief and range of motion in the first 24 hours, LB PAI resulted in better early functional recovery (straight leg raise) and physical function scores at 3 months postoperatively. Both interventions provided excellent pain relief overall.
population_specificity: 373 patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intraoperative periarticular injection with liposomal bupivacaine).

study_goal: To determine the effects of tDCS on cognition, mobility, and dual-task standing and walking in older adults with mild-to-moderate motor and cognitive impairments.
results_summary: tDCS improved executive function and dual-task standing and walking, with effects persisting for 2 weeks, but had no effect on mobility or depression scores.
population_specificity: Nondemented, ambulatory adults aged ≥65 years with slow walking speed and executive dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of upper limb multilevel surgery on segmental alignment, performance, and functional use in children with hemiplegic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found that surgery could induce segmental, aesthetic, or functional changes depending on the manipulation pattern, emphasizing the importance of analyzing spontaneous manipulation abilities and daily use.
population_specificity: Children affected by hemiplegic cerebral palsy who underwent upper limb multilevel surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the aesthetic perceptions and psychosocial impact of patients after undergoing intracoronary bleaching using hydrogen peroxide (35%) and carbamide peroxide (37%) via the walking bleach technique.
results_summary: Both bleaching agents were highly effective, with stable color changes observed up to 3 months post-treatment. Patients showed significant improvements in aesthetic perception and psychosocial factors, as measured by OHIP and PIDAQ questionnaires.
population_specificity: Patients with non-vital teeth discoloration (n=50, divided into two groups of 25 each).
effective_dosage: Hydrogen peroxide 35% and carbamide peroxide 37%, applied in four sessions.
study_duration: Four sessions, with follow-up evaluations at 1 week, 1 month, and 3 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between step count and changes in blood pressure (BP) through a systematic review and meta-analysis of studies involving brisk walking with a pedometer.
results_summary: The study found that increased step count was significantly associated with improved BP (systolic BP decreased by -3.1 mm Hg, diastolic BP by -1.6 mm Hg), but walking 10,000 steps a day did not significantly differ in BP reduction compared to lower step counts. Meta-regression indicated a systolic BP decrease of ~4 mm Hg per 2000 additional steps daily.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
effective_dosage: Not specified (step count varied, with some trials targeting 10,000 steps/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) for treating non-healing diabetic wounds, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that ADSCs enhanced diabetic wound healing through mechanisms like increased epithelialization, anti-inflammatory effects, and angiogenic cytokine release, with some clinical trials showing improved ulcer evolution and walking distances.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 12-week healthy lifestyle program, including walking, on weight control and cardiometabolic risk reduction in obese African American adults.
results_summary: The study found that walking steps increased, though not significantly, while sedentary behavior was associated with less favorable changes in total cholesterol and TNF-α. Significant improvements were seen in HbA1c and body fat percentage (in males).
population_specificity: Obese African American adults (n=30, 22 females, mean age 56.7±11.4 years, BMI 37.4±6.7 kg/m2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aerobic exercise training (walking/running) alone and combined with vitamin C supplementation on rhinitis symptoms in allergic rhinitis patients.
results_summary: Both exercise groups (EX and EX + Vit.C) showed increased peak aerobic capacity, improved nasal inspiratory flow, reduced rhinitis symptoms, and favorable cytokine profile changes compared to the control group. The addition of vitamin C did not demonstrate clear additional benefits over exercise alone.
population_specificity: Allergic rhinitis patients (n=27, divided into 3 groups).
effective_dosage: Walking/running at 65-70% heart rate reserve for 30 min per session, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of balance training on walking capacity, balance-specific performance, and other functional outcomes in elderly individuals following total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: Balance training significantly improved walking capacity, balance-specific performance, and functional outcomes in elderly individuals post-TKA, with standardized mean differences indicating moderate to large effect sizes. High inter-trial heterogeneity was noted for some outcome measures.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (65+ years) who underwent total knee arthroplasty.
effective_dosage: Not specified (balance exercises compared to control interventions without balance exercises).
