study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors associated with committed participation in an amputee wellness-walking program and determine the benefits of committed participation.
results_summary: Committed participants were more likely to diet, have better balance ability, and have more recent amputations than one-time-only participants. Balance confidence and functional improvements after three sessions were not significant.
population_specificity: Amputees (average age 55.7 years, 68.4% men, 78.4% White, 51.8% with dysvascular amputations, 40.5% with prosthetic knees, 49.1% independent community walkers).
study_duration: 3 sessions within 3 years for committed participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the efficacy and safety of mTOR inhibitors in patients with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that mTOR inhibitors improved forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) in LAM patients, but the abstract does not mention Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors for falls in hospitalized adult patients, with a focus on walking limitations.
results_summary: The study found that walking limitation was a significant risk factor for falls, with an odds ratio of 4.34 (2.05 to 9.14), indicating a strong association. Other factors like disorientation, frequent urination, and medication use also contributed to fall risk.
population_specificity: Hospitalized adult patients in clinical and surgical units of a teaching hospital in Southern Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of differently cued and non-cued motor imagery (MI) on walking, fatigue, and quality of life in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: All interventions (MVMI, MMI, and MI) significantly improved walking speed and distance, with MVMI showing superior results. Cued MI also improved fatigue and quality of life, with MVMI again demonstrating the greatest benefits.
population_specificity: 60 people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) with mild to moderate disability.
effective_dosage: 17 minutes of cued or non-cued MI of walking, six times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of LIPUS on pain relief and functional recovery in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that LIPUS treatment resulted in a decrease in pain intensity and improved knee functional recovery, with no reported adverse effects. However, more evidence is needed to confirm its effectiveness in improving walking ability.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cessation of biventricular pacing in super-responders of cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) affects clinical and functional outcomes, including walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) between the ceased pacing (CeP) and continued pacing (CoP) groups at 3 and 6 months, but left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was significantly reduced in the CeP group after 6 months.
population_specificity: Super-responders of cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) (21 patients).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study involved cessation or continuation of pacing, not a dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical usefulness of anterior-posterior displacement of center of pressure (AP_CoP) parameters in assessing gait function in subacute post-stroke hemiplegia.
results_summary: AP_CoP parameters were shorter in the gait with aid group compared to the gait with independence group, and longer AP_CoP correlated with better functional ambulatory category, walking speed, stride length, and symmetry of single support phase proportion.
population_specificity: Participants with post-stroke hemiplegia (19 in gait with aid group, 21 in gait with independence group, and 21 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the reliability of gaitography for prosthetic gait analysis by assessing within-method repeatability and between-methods agreement for temporal gait events and characteristics.
results_summary: The study found better between-methods reproducibility than within-method repeatability for temporal gait characteristics, with good agreement for step times, stride times, and foot-contact events, but small systematic biases for foot-off events and related parameters.
population_specificity: Ten male proficient prosthetic walkers with unilateral trans-femoral or trans-tibial amputation.
study_duration: Walking sessions on separate days (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of exercise interventions, particularly walking, in improving sleep deficiency among women with breast cancer.
results_summary: Walking, primarily during chemotherapy, was associated with postintervention improvement in sleep deficiency in 11 out of 15 studies. Other interventions like yoga, qigong, and dance showed no significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer, particularly those undergoing chemotherapy.
study_duration: Primarily during chemotherapy (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and quantify problems in functioning and mobility for persons with lower-limb amputation using the International Classification of Function, Health and Disability.
results_summary: The study found that walking, design and construction of buildings, and sensation of pain were the most frequently occurring functional challenges for persons with lower-limb amputation, with similar patterns across six countries. The International Classification of Function, Health and Disability was deemed useful for global communication among clinicians.
population_specificity: Persons with lower-limb amputation and clinicians involved in their pre- and post-amputation care.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and feasibility of electrical muscle stimulation (EMS) in patients undergoing intensive chemotherapy or stem cell transplantation, and its impact on physical and psychological performance.
results_summary: EMS was found to be feasible and safe, with minor adverse events (hematoma and muscle pain). Physical performance (6MWD and SPPB) showed minimal decline, while fatigue levels and quality of life remained stable throughout therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with hematological malignancies undergoing autologous HSCT (n=13), allogeneic HSCT (n=11), or intensive chemotherapy (n=21).
study_duration: From before chemotherapy (T1) to discharge from hospital (T2)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank psychosocial interventions, including walking programs, for improving cognition in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that walking programs (WP) showed better cognitive outcomes compared to control groups, as measured by MMSE, and had better compliance than group exercise and art therapy. However, combined cognitive training and acetylcholinesterase inhibitors were more effective than walking programs alone.
population_specificity: Older adults with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish reference values and test-retest reliability for usual and maximal 4-meter gait speed in adults.
results_summary: Mean usual gait speed was 1.12 m/s, and maximal speed was 1.61 m/s, with significant variations by age, sex, and gait condition. Test-retest reliability was fair, with high minimal detectable changes, limiting usefulness for tracking individual changes.
population_specificity: 1,320 men and women aged 18-85 from the NIH Toolbox norming study across 10 U.S. cities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the impact of ankle-foot orthoses on gait one year postoperatively in children with bilateral cerebral palsy and identify predictors for clinically important improvement.
results_summary: The study found that walking with ankle-foot orthoses significantly improved step length, velocity, and knee moments compared to barefoot walking, with stronger effects observed in children with more pronounced preoperative gait dysfunction.
population_specificity: 34 ambulating children (12 girls, 22 boys) aged 6-17 years with bilateral spastic cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether interrupting prolonged sitting with short bouts of moderate-intensity walking improves glucose metabolism in children with overweight or obesity without affecting dietary intake.
results_summary: The study found that interrupting sitting with brief walking reduced insulin and C-peptide levels during an oral glucose tolerance test, indicating improved glucose metabolism, without significantly increasing energy intake.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese children aged 7-11 years (BMI ≥85th percentile).
effective_dosage: 3 minutes of moderate-intensity walking (at 80% of ventilatory threshold) every 30 minutes for 3 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of knee adduction moment (KAM) gait retraining compared to walking exercise in reducing KAM and improving symptoms in patients with early knee osteoarthritis over 6 months.
results_summary: Gait retraining significantly reduced KAM and improved WOMAC osteoarthritis index scores immediately post-training and at 6-month follow-up, while walking exercise showed no significant changes in KAM or WOMAC scores. No significant effect was observed for knee flexion moment (KFM) in either group.
population_specificity: 23 patients with early knee osteoarthritis (20 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding botulinum toxin (BoNT-A) to comprehensive rehabilitation improved motor impairments, gait, and goal attainment in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in treatment effects between the BoNT-A plus rehabilitation group and the rehabilitation-only group, except for a minor advantage in the angle-of-catch of the rectus femoris favoring rehabilitation without BoNT-A. Results remained similar at follow-up.
population_specificity: Children with spastic cerebral palsy (GMFCS levels I-III), aged 4-12 years, indicated for BoNT-A treatment for mobility problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an attribution-retraining program (¡Caminemos!) combined with an exercise class could increase walking behavior among physically inactive older Hispanics/Latinos compared to exercise alone.
results_summary: Both the treatment (attribution retraining) and control (generic health education) groups increased their mean steps/day, with the treatment group showing greater improvement at 12 months, though the difference was not sustained at 24 months. The intervention successfully improved walking behavior in the short term.
population_specificity: Older Hispanics/Latinos (≥60 years, 77% female, 76% with income <$20,000).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether action observation (AO) and action observation combined with motor imagery (AO + MI) could modulate spinal reflex excitability (H-reflex) during walking phases.
results_summary: The study found that AO + MI significantly increased H-reflex compared to AO alone, regardless of walking phase, and that AO modulated H-reflex depending on the observed phase, suggesting different neural effects between AO and AO + MI.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely individuals with motor impairments, but exact population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and clinical effects of using a superficial peroneal fasciocutaneous flap to repair soft tissue loss in the anterior and middle regions of children's feet, focusing on improving walking function and appearance.
results_summary: The study found that all flaps survived with primary healing, and follow-up showed satisfactory flap color, texture, and appearance, with normal walking function and foot blood circulation. The method was deemed effective for improving recipient area appearance and walking function due to reliable blood supply and convenient rotation.
population_specificity: 8 children (median age 6.5 years) with soft tissue loss in the anterior and middle regions of their feet.
study_duration: Postoperative follow-up ranged from 3 to 12 months (median 7.5 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of inspiratory muscle training on inspiratory muscle strength, functional capacity (including walking distance), and dyspnoea in patients with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: Inspiratory muscle training improved maximal inspiratory pressure, walking distance, and dyspnoea, particularly at 60% of maximal inspiratory pressure, six times per week for 12 weeks. The findings were consistent across studies, though limited by a small number of heterogeneous trials.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure.
effective_dosage: 30% to 60% of maximal inspiratory pressure, three to seven times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of physical activity, including brisk walking, on fasting blood glucose and lipid profile among low-income housewives.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of physical activity on glucose levels and most lipid profiles, except for a reduction in triglycerides. Both intervention and control groups showed decreased physical activity levels over time.
population_specificity: Low-income housewives in Klang Valley.
effective_dosage: Not specified (brisk walking was part of an intervention package including dumbbell exercise, physical activity diary, and group exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of treadmill training (TT) combined with proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation lower-leg taping (PNFLT) on walking and balance ability in stroke patients.
results_summary: The PNFLT-TT group showed significant improvements in walking (6MWT, 10MWT) and balance (TUG) compared to the TT-only group, with statistically significant differences (P<0.05 and P<0.01). The intervention was effective in enhancing walking and balance in stroke patients.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (n=27, control=13, experimental=14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the morbidity and mortality of sarcopenia and frailty in peritoneal dialysis (PD) patients and investigate related MIA syndrome factors.
results_summary: The study found that sarcopenia and frailty were associated with higher mortality risk in PD patients, with CFS (Clinical Frailty Scale) being a significant predictor. Slow walking was linked to sarcopenia, but the abstract does not detail walking-specific outcomes.
population_specificity: Peritoneal dialysis (PD) patients (n=119).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of transcutaneous oxygen pressure measurement as a diagnostic tool for identifying vascular or non-vascular causes of exertional lower limb pain during walking in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found that transcutaneous oxygen pressure measurement provides reliable estimation of regional blood flow impairment during exercise, offering more accurate diagnostic information compared to traditional non-invasive vascular tests. It can also detect systemic oxygen pressure changes, aiding in screening for occult pulmonary disease.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with exertional lower limb pain suspected of arterial claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of community-based Baduanjin exercise on self-efficacy in adults with cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The study found that Baduanjin exercise significantly improved self-efficacy scores in cardiovascular disease patients compared to the control group, with notable increases in confidence to manage fatigue, physical discomfort, emotional distress, and daily activities.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults with cardiovascular disease, aged primarily 65 or older, with low education and income levels.
effective_dosage: 16 weeks of Baduanjin exercise training (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to evaluate the feasibility and outcomes of MitraClip therapy as an alternative to surgery for patients with radiotherapy-related mitral regurgitation.
results_summary: The study found that MitraClip improved mitral regurgitation (residual MR ≤2+) without significant stenosis, though late stenosis could occur due to sustained reactive damage from radiation.
population_specificity: Patients with radiotherapy-related mitral regurgitation (15 of 33 screened).

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of electromechanical exoskeleton-assisted gait training on walking ability in stroke patients, focusing on ambulatory function, muscle strength, balance, gait speed, and capacity.
results_summary: Both conventional and exoskeleton-assisted gait training improved functional ambulatory category (FAC), but only the exoskeleton group showed statistically significant improvements. Secondary outcomes improved in both groups, but no significant differences were found after adjusting for age and stroke duration.
population_specificity: Individuals (N=40) with stroke who could stand alone.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per day, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effectiveness of a prototype LSS belt versus a lumbar support in improving walking ability in patients with degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Both the prototype LSS belt and lumbar support significantly improved walking distance, but there was no significant difference between the two interventions. A higher proportion of participants in the lumbar support group (82%) achieved at least 30% improvement in walking distance compared to the LSS belt group (62%), though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50+ with neurogenic claudication, imaging-confirmed degenerative LSS, and limited walking ability (n=104).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a six-month home-based exercise intervention, primarily brisk walking, could improve health-related quality of life (HRQOL) and reduce cancer-related fatigue (CRF) in ovarian cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise intervention significantly improved physical HRQOL and fatigue scores compared to the control group, though no differences were observed in mental HRQOL. The exercise group showed a statistically significant improvement in fatigue, while the control group did not.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer survivors (n=144, with 113 completing the six-month assessment).
effective_dosage: 166.0±66.1 minutes per week of exercise (primarily brisk walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the longitudinal relationship between exercise capacity (measured by sit-to-stand and 6-minute walking tests) and daily physical activity (steps per day) in COPD patients over time.
results_summary: The study found that COPD patients experienced a significant annual decline in daily physical activity (steps per day) while their exercise capacity (sit-to-stand and 6-minute walking tests) remained stable, suggesting that reduced physical activity is not directly linked to declining exercise tolerance.
population_specificity: 202 COPD patients (17% risk group A, 49% B, 4% C, 34% D) recruited from pulmonary outpatient clinics or hospital settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare knee moments calculated using inverse dynamics versus a cross product function in people with knee osteoarthritis during walking.
results_summary: The study found high correlations (r > 0.9) between the two methods for calculating knee moments, with the cross product function yielding absolute values less than 10% of those from inverse dynamics for key metrics like peak knee adduction moment. This suggests the cross product function could simplify knee moment calculations without significant loss of accuracy.
population_specificity: 74 people with moderate knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review barriers and enablers to walking exercise in individuals with intermittent claudication (IC) to inform patient-centered self-management interventions.
results_summary: The review identified key barriers (e.g., comorbid health concerns, walking-induced pain, lack of knowledge) and enablers (e.g., cognitive coping strategies, support systems, specific walking instructions) influencing walking in IC patients, suggesting the need for multidimensional interventions.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and intermittent claudication (IC) (n = 4376 across 18 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize evidence on dual-task standing and walking in people with lower limb amputation and discuss implications for future research.
results_summary: The study found that dual-task interference in standing is greater for people with lower limb amputation than non-amputees, and microprocessor-controlled knees improve dual-task walking performance for those with limited mobility compared to non-microprocessor-controlled knees.
population_specificity: People with lower limb amputation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical color rebound of whitening patients' tooth discoloration using the walking bleaching technique and assess its impact on psychological and aesthetic self-perception at the one-year follow-up.
results_summary: The walking bleaching technique was highly effective with minimal color rebound in nonvital teeth, showing no significant differences between hydrogen peroxide and carbamide peroxide groups. It also had a positive effect on patients' psychological impact, as indicated by reduced PIDAQ scores.
population_specificity: Fifty participants with nonvital tooth discoloration.
effective_dosage: 35% hydrogen peroxide and 37% carbamide peroxide, administered over four sessions.
study_duration: Four sessions, with a one-year follow-up.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of backward gait training on balance, gross motor function, and gait parameters in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: Backward gait training showed positive effects on balance, gross motor function, step length, and walking speed in children with cerebral palsy, with level 1b evidence for some outcomes compared to no intervention or forward gait training. The clinical heterogeneity of studies prevented meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy
effective_dosage: 15 to 25 minutes, three times a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of strengthening specific muscles (ankle plantarflexion, hip abduction, and trunk muscles) to improve gait performance in people with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The 8-week strengthening intervention led to significant improvements in muscle strength (23.1-47.6%), gait speed (-13.4%), gait endurance (41.56 m), and self-reported gait-related participation (-10.5 points on the MS Walking Scale-12). All participants reported satisfaction, and adherence rates were high (87% supervised, 75% home sessions).
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (Expanded Disability Status Scale: 3.5-5.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and radiological outcomes of posterolateral fusion (PLF) versus posterior lumbar interbody fusion (PLIF) in treating lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) and degenerative instability, focusing on pain relief, quality of life, and spinal alignment.
results_summary: PLF showed better clinical outcomes than PLIF, including greater reductions in low back pain and radicular pain (measured by VAS), improved quality of life (measured by ODI), and better correction of spinal alignment (Cobb angle and sagittal balance) at 24 months postoperatively. However, PLF had a lower fusion rate compared to PLIF.
population_specificity: 88 patients with LSS and degenerative lumbar spine instability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding early in-bed leg cycling and electrical muscle stimulation to standardized rehabilitation improved muscle strength and walking capability in ICU patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in muscle strength, walking capability, or ventilator-free days with the intervention compared to usual care. No significant differences were observed in long-term functional autonomy or quality of life at 6 months.
population_specificity: Critically ill adult patients in an ICU (mean age 66, 36% women, 78% on mechanical ventilation).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated; follow-up lasted 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of vascular closure devices (VCDs) versus manual compression (MC) for hemostasis after transfemoral percutaneous coronary interventions (PCIs), focusing on vascular complications, pain, and discomfort.
results_summary: VCDs showed more successful hemostasis and reduced pain/discomfort compared to MC, but had a higher relative risk of bruising, hematomas, and need for further treatment. Both groups experienced increased pain and discomfort post-PCI, though VCD patients reported less severe symptoms.
population_specificity: 73 patients undergoing transfemoral PCI in China (34 VCD group, 39 MC group).
study_duration: Not specified (study conducted between January 2014 and February 2015).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the association between walking biomechanics and falls in people with Parkinson's disease (PD) to identify risk factors and guide interventions.
results_summary: The study found that slower walking speed, lower cadence, shorter strides, and more mediolateral head and pelvis motion were associated with higher falls risk in PD patients. Findings were consistent across prospective and retrospective studies.
population_specificity: People with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (PD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between frailty, sarcopenia, and protein-energy wasting in elderly Japanese dialysis patients, with walking speed as one component of frailty assessment.
results_summary: The study highlighted that decreased walking speed is a marker of frailty in dialysis patients, which is associated with higher mortality, and emphasized the importance of adequate protein and calorie intake to prevent sarcopenia and frailty.
population_specificity: Elderly Japanese dialysis patients with frailty and sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of customized vestibular rehabilitation training on gait stability in patients with subacute stroke.
results_summary: The VR group showed higher walking speed and stride length compared to the control group, but no significant difference in trunk stability. Significant differences were also observed in clinical scale scores between the groups.
population_specificity: 25 inpatients (12 male, mean age 64.1±12.1 years) with subacute stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine transfer effects and the sustainability of a specific dual-task (DT) training involving walking in patients with dementia.
results_summary: The study found that specific DT training significantly improved performance in trained tasks, with partial transfer to semi-trained tasks but no transfer to untrained tasks. Training gains in the trained condition were sustained for at least 3 months, while gains in semi-trained tasks were not sustained.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate dementia (Mini-Mental State Examination: 21.9 ± 2.8 points).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved a 10-week DT training program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether water-based exercise (WBE) combined with land-based exercise (LBE) improved motor functions, walking, balance, and quality of life in stroke patients compared to LBE alone.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in most parameters, but the WBE+LBE group had greater improvement in vitality (SF-36), while the LBE group showed better balance (BBS). No additional benefit was found for WBE+LBE over LBE alone in other measures.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with hemiplegia (n=60).
effective_dosage: Study group: WBE (3/week) + LBE (2/week); Control group: LBE (5/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the improvement in functional class and 6-minute walking test (6MWT) performance in patients with advanced heart failure and multiple comorbidities after treatment with sacubitril-valsartan.
results_summary: After treatment, patients achieved an improvement of 55.68 meters or more in the 6MWT, and 91% showed improvement in NYHA functional class, indicating enhanced functionality and symptom relief.
population_specificity: 65 multimorbidity patients (mean age 78.6 years, 68% male) with severe symptomatic HFrEF (74% NYHA Class IV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether commercially available wearable activity monitors and smartphone applications effectively increase physical activity levels in people with stroke.
results_summary: The study found no clear evidence that activity monitors significantly increased step counts or moderate-to-vigorous physical activity in stroke patients, though one trial noted a small increase in moderate-intensity activity. Overall, the evidence was deemed insufficient to support their use for increasing physical activity post-stroke.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18+ with a diagnosis of stroke, either in hospital or living in the community.
study_duration: Varied by study (from less than one week to a median of 51 months post-stroke)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online-delivered walking intervention in increasing physical activity and reducing sedentary time among rural Australian adults.
results_summary: Both groups showed increased physical activity and decreased sedentary time during the intervention, but only the intervention group maintained improvements in light physical activity at six-month follow-up. By twelve-month follow-up, most post-intervention improvements had disappeared, indicating a need for strategies to enhance long-term adherence.
population_specificity: Rural South Australian adults (n=171; mean age 50.6±12.5 years).
effective_dosage: Personalized step goals based on ratings of perceived exertion and daily affect (intervention group); generic step goals (comparison group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which individual symptoms of Bortezomib-induced peripheral neuropathy (BIPN) were improved by acupuncture, with a focus on trouble walking and other sensory/motor dysfunctions.
results_summary: Acupuncture significantly reduced BIPN symptoms, particularly numbness/tingling in hands/feet, discomfort, trouble walking, cold sensitivity, and unpleasant feelings, as measured by NPS and FACT/GOG-Ntx scores. Motor dysfunction and hearing also improved significantly.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple myeloma treated with bortezomib who developed BIPN grade 2 or above.
effective_dosage: 10 acupuncture treatments over 10 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a standardized scanning and mobility program versus individualized therapy for improving scanning ability while walking and quality of life in stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia.
results_summary: No significant differences were found in scanning ability while walking between the intervention groups at 7 weeks or 3 months, but the standardized program improved quality of life (QOL) measures at 3 months.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with homonymous hemianopia (mean age 65±4.3, 54% male, mean time since stroke 51±52.3 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical outcomes, including patient activity and hip function, between two surgical approaches (direct anterior vs. transgluteal lateral) for total hip arthroplasty (THA) over 12 months.
results_summary: The study found that THA via the direct anterior approach resulted in significantly higher patient activity (measured by step cycles and walking distance) compared to the transgluteal approach, though hip function (measured by HHS) showed no significant difference. Physical component scores (SF-36 PCS) also favored the anterior approach.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (123 arthroplasties evaluated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of metformin on clinically relevant outcomes, including 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) decline, in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in disease progression, including 6MWD decline, between metformin users and nonmetformin users. A higher proportion of metformin users had a relative FVC decline of ≥5%, but overall, metformin showed no effect on clinically relevant outcomes in IPF patients.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), including subgroups with diabetes and/or hyperglycemia (IGT-diabetes population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the implementation of a lifestyle intervention, including walking groups, to reduce diabetes risk in high-risk individuals in Kerala, India.
results_summary: The study found that 41% of participants engaged in community-based walking groups, and the program was feasible and acceptable for lifestyle changes. Participant interest and usefulness ratings were positive, though attendance barriers like time and location were noted.
population_specificity: High-risk individuals for type 2 diabetes mellitus in Kerala, India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of daily use of flat flexible shoes versus stable supportive shoes on knee osteoarthritis clinical outcomes over 6 months.
results_summary: The study will determine whether flat flexible shoes improve knee pain and physical function compared to stable supportive shoes, with outcomes measured using validated scales. Results will inform evidence-based footwear recommendations for knee OA management.
population_specificity: 164 people with symptomatic medial tibiofemoral osteoarthritis of moderate to severe radiographic severity (Kellgren and Lawrence Grade 3 & 4).
effective_dosage: Daily wear of allocated shoes for a minimum of 6 hours per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the grades of recommendation regarding the benefits of hippotherapy (horseback riding therapy) for improving walking and motor function in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The review found that hippotherapy improved gross motor function, walking speed, stride length, postural alignment, and daily life activities in children with cerebral palsy, with additional benefits in psychological factors and quality of life.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the wear rate, particle size, and particle shape of conventional polyethylene (CPE) versus highly cross-linked polyethylene (HXLPE) liners in total ankle arthroplasty under simulated walking conditions.
results_summary: HXLPE liners showed a significantly lower wear rate (2.0 mg/MC vs. 16.7 mg/MC for CPE) and produced fewer, rounder particles, suggesting better wear characteristics for total ankle arthroplasty. The findings indicate HXLPE may reduce osteolysis risk compared to CPE.
population_specificity: Simulated total ankle arthroplasty implants (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare demographic and clinical characteristics of children with cerebral palsy (CP) who had stored cord blood (CB) to those identified in a population-based study, focusing on functional mobility (including walking ability).
results_summary: The study found that children with CP and stored CB had similar clinical severity and comorbidity profiles (including gross motor function and walking ability) compared to a broader population sample, despite demographic differences.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (CP) who had stored cord blood (CB) and those identified in a population-based study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to modify and simplify 24-form Tai Chi for COPD patients and evaluate its effects on lung function, exercise capacity, dyspnea, and health status.
results_summary: The modified 6-form Tai Chi was easy to learn, safe, and effective in improving lung function, exercise capacity, and health status while preventing dyspnea worsening in COPD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD (stages II to IV).
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants could grasp the routine in about 3 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of surgical treatment for spinal metastases, including its impact on walking ability and pain relief.
results_summary: Post-surgery, 69.4% of patients regained Frankel Grade E mobility, and only 5.3% could not walk. Pain levels significantly decreased from 4.6 to 2.4 (p<0.001).
population_specificity: Patients with spinal metastases treated at seven spine surgery centers in France (2011-2015).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Baduanjin exercise, as an adjunct to standard cardiac rehabilitation, improves cardiopulmonary function, exercise tolerance, and quality of life in patients with chronic heart failure caused by coronary artery disease.
results_summary: The study found that Baduanjin exercise combined with conventional cardiac rehabilitation improved walking distance in the 6-minute walk test (primary outcome) and peak oxygen uptake (secondary outcome), suggesting enhanced exercise tolerance and cardiopulmonary function in ischemic CHF patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure caused by coronary artery disease.
effective_dosage: 45-minute Baduanjin exercise sessions twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of aerobic exercise, including high vs. low intensity, in treating anxiety compared to waiting list controls.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise was effective in reducing anxiety compared to waiting list controls, with high intensity exercise showing greater benefits than low intensity. No significant difference was found between diagnosed anxiety disorders and elevated anxiety on rating scales.
population_specificity: Patients with diagnosed anxiety disorders or clinically raised anxiety levels on validated rating scales.
effective_dosage: Any aerobic exercise program for at least two weeks or high intensity exercise for at least two weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether measures of physical performance (including walking speed) and appendicular lean mass predict incident fractures in older men independently of FRAX probability.
results_summary: The study investigated the relationship between physical performance measures (including walking speed) and fracture risk, suggesting these measures may provide additional predictive value beyond FRAX probability for fractures in older men.
population_specificity: Older men from Sweden, Hong Kong, and the United States.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a smartphone app-based behavior change program could effectively promote active transportation (walking or cycling) and increase physical activity in adults.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a randomized controlled trial design but does not report final results; efficacy will be measured by changes in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and active transportation time post-intervention.
population_specificity: Adults aged 20-65 years in Stockholm County, Sweden.
effective_dosage: Not specified (behavior change program via app for 3 months).
study_duration: 3-month intervention with follow-up at 6 months post-randomization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher intensity and dose exercise programs improve walking ability more than usual inpatient physical therapy care in stroke rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study will assess the impact of different exercise intensities and doses on walking ability, functional independence, cognitive function, and quality of life, with outcomes measured at four time points.
population_specificity: Seventy-five individuals undergoing inpatient rehabilitation for stroke across seven sites in Canada.
effective_dosage: Three treatment programs, 5 days/week for four weeks, with exertion (heart rate) and repetitions (step count) monitored.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi Chuan and brisk walking on balance improvement in elderly women and determine the required training duration for significant results.
results_summary: Brisk walking improved balance with eyes open by the 12th week and with eyes closed by the 16th week. The study found that 16 weeks of brisk walking were essential for significant balance improvement with eyes closed in elderly women.
population_specificity: Elderly women aged 60-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers evaluated the effectiveness and safety of pregabalin on pain relief post herniorrhaphy, specifically assessing pain during walking and lying positions.
results_summary: The pregabalin group had less pain and lower visual analog scale scores at 12 and 24 hours and at 3 days post-surgery, with reduced pethidine consumption compared to the placebo group. Adverse effects were limited to the first 12 hours.
population_specificity: 60 men undergoing unilateral inguinal herniorrhaphy under spinal anesthesia.
effective_dosage: 300 mg oral pregabalin 2 hours before surgery, then 150 mg at 12 and 24 hours post-surgery.
study_duration: 7 days (assessments at 12h, 24h, 3 days, and 7 days post-surgery).

study_goal: The researchers sought to compare the effects of proximal femoral nail anti-rotation (PFNA) and dynamic hip screw (DHS) helical blade treatments on functional recovery, including walking speed, in elderly osteoporosis patients with femoral intertrochanteric fractures.
results_summary: PFNA treatment resulted in superior post-operative outcomes, including improved 10-meter walking speed, reduced pain, better bone mineral density, and fewer complications compared to DHS. The observation group showed faster fracture healing and weight-bearing times, enhancing mobility recovery.
population_specificity: Elderly osteoporosis patients with femoral intertrochanteric fractures (n=80, aged unspecified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of F-PBR06 and C-PBR28 PET radioligands in detecting microglial activation in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients and assess their association with physical disability.
results_summary: F-PBR06 and C-PBR28 showed moderate correlation in whole-brain and supratentorial white matter but not in other regions. F-PBR06 demonstrated higher clinical relevance, with its SUVRmax correlating with disability scores and walking speed in MS patients.
population_specificity: Six patients with MS (4 women; mean age 32.1 ± 4.9 years; Expanded Disability Status Scale score 2.3 ± 1.2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of total hip arthroplasty (THA) and hip arthrodesis (HA) in treating coxotuberculosis, focusing on postoperative recovery and walking-related metrics.
results_summary: THA showed superior postoperative outcomes compared to HA, including shorter recovery times (postoperative start walking time, weight-bearing time), better pain and function scores (VAS, HHS), and fewer complications. HA had shorter operation times and less blood loss but poorer functional recovery.
population_specificity: 40 patients with coxotuberculosis treated at a single hospital from 2011 to 2016.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether autologous bone marrow-derived mononuclear cell (BM-MNC) therapy was effective for improving outcomes in no-option peripheral artery disease (PAD) patients, focusing on amputation rates and walking distance.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between BM-MNC therapy and placebo in primary outcomes (amputations, pain-free walking distance) or secondary outcomes (ankle brachial index, pain scores, quality of life). The results did not support the clinical use of BM-MNC therapy for PAD.
population_specificity: No-option, end-stage PAD patients (mean age 58.2 years, 58% male) without diabetes or imminent amputation need.
effective_dosage: 40 mL of concentrated BM-MNCs or placebo, injected intramuscularly at 40 locations in the calf muscle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors for low instrumental activities of daily living (IADL) after a hip fracture to improve postoperative care.
results_summary: Only 24% of patients returned to baseline IADL levels at 3 months post-fracture, increasing to 29% at 12 months. Older age, prefracture living with a partner, home living, use of walking aids, and longer hospital stays were associated with greater IADL loss.
population_specificity: 480 hip fracture patients, primarily older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of screening for peripheral artery disease (PAD) and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk using the ankle-brachial index (ABI) in asymptomatic adults, including the potential benefits of interventions like supervised exercise and physical therapy.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to determine the benefits of screening for PAD with the ABI or the effectiveness of exercise therapy in asymptomatic adults. Two studies showed no benefit from exercise therapy, and no significant benefits were observed from using the ABI to manage aspirin therapy.
population_specificity: Generally asymptomatic adults, including individuals with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of screening for peripheral artery disease (PAD) using the ankle-brachial index (ABI) and the effectiveness of treatments like aspirin and exercise in asymptomatic populations.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefits of PAD screening with ABI or aspirin treatment for cardiovascular outcomes in asymptomatic populations. Exercise trials showed no differences in quality of life or walking performance.
population_specificity: Unselected or generally asymptomatic adults with no known cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of gene therapy (pl-VEGF165) for treating chronic lower limb ischemia in patients with atherosclerotic genesis.
results_summary: The study found that gene therapy significantly improved pain-free walking distance (288% increase) and limb salvage rates (95% in treatment group vs. 67% in control group) over 5 years, with no statistically significant differences in major adverse events between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic lower limb ischemia of atherosclerotic origin (36 in treatment group, 12 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of smart home sensor technologies, including walking speed monitoring, for early detection of mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that walking speed and activity/motion in the house were effective indicators of MCI in real-life monitoring, while scenario-based assessments also identified MCI through task performance metrics. Smart home technologies showed promise for early MCI screening despite technological limitations.
population_specificity: Aging individuals, particularly those at risk for or showing signs of mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent technological advances in wearable sensors, biofeedback devices, and assistive robots for gait rehabilitation to improve convenience, efficiency, and personalization.
results_summary: The study highlights the integration of smart sensing, big data analytics, and assistive robotics into gait rehabilitation, enabling nonintrusive monitoring, complex gait analysis, and real-time decision-making. It also discusses open problems and future directions to enhance safety, efficiency, and usability of these technologies.
population_specificity: Individuals requiring walking assistance, particularly those in need of gait rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether step counter use increases physical activity or improves exercise capacity in COPD patients.
results_summary: Step counter use increased physical activity (equivalent to 1026 steps/day) and improved exercise capacity (equivalent to 11.6 m in the 6-min walking distance) in COPD patients, particularly in those receiving pulmonary rehabilitation, but showed no significant benefits for severe COPD patients or interventions lasting ≥6 months.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe COPD (1316 participants across 15 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of riociguat treatment on pulmonary arterial hypertension, particularly its effects on walking distance (6-MWD) and other clinical outcomes.
results_summary: Riociguat treatment significantly improved six-minute walking distance (6-MWD), EQ-5D score, and cardiac index while reducing Living With Pulmonary Hypertension (LPH) score and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR), with no increase in adverse events compared to control.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and regulatory approval status of prolonged-release 4-aminopyridine for improving walking in patients with multiple sclerosis and other neurological disorders.
results_summary: The study found that prolonged-release 4-aminopyridine was effective in improving walking in about one-third of multiple sclerosis patients and showed potential efficacy in broader neurological conditions. Regulatory approvals (FDA and EMA) supported its clinical use after additional studies.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis and other neurological disorders.
